newsitem.title: CHINA: GUANGDONG BREWERY SEEN STRONG ON DEBUT.
newsitem.headline: GUANGDONG BREWERY SEEN STRONG ON DEBUT.

text.p: Shares of Guangdong Brewery Holdings Ltd, a unit of Guangdong Investment Ltd, are poised for a strong debut on Friday, aided by strong parent backing and hopes of asset injections, analysts said.

"Its debut is seen to be strong. There is still a great demand for a quality red-chip, especially as the company is backed up by well-known Guangdong Investment," said Pamela Lam, analyst at Pacific Challenge Securities.
Brokers said the recent strong demand for Chinese parent backed companies would boost performance of the issue.

Guangdong Brewery offered 350 million shares at HK$1.80 each. Some 218.4 million shares were offered to Guangdong Investment's existing shareholders and 35 million shares were offered to the employees.
A further 96.6 million shares offered for public subscription was 38.5 times oversubscribed.
Analysts said a warm subscription response had indicated strong investor strong interest.
However, some said a relatively high offer price could dampen investor interest in the short run.

"The subscription response was okay but not as exciting as before," said Ben Kwong, director of research of Dharmala Securities. "Concern over its relatively high price to earnings multiple (P.E.) can dampen its upside in the short run."
The issue was offered at a proforma fully-diluted P.E. of 20.9 times.
"In view of its future earnings growth and possible injection of assets, it is worth holding for long term investment," Lam said.
Analysts said the company's earnings outlook was seen strong due to an expected rise in beer consumption, in line with economic growth in China.
Guangdong Brewery is involved in production, distribution, and sales of "Kingway" beer.
The company has two production plants in Shenzhen and it plans to produce 400,000 tonnes of beer by early 1998.
It also has a sales network of about 200 distributors located across the country.
The company forecasts its profit to be not less than HK$90 million for the year ending in December 1997, up from HK$62.27 million profit in 1996.
